metadata.titel_preek: Trinity Sunday / Second Sunday After Pentecost (Psalm 130)

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God, whose inner nature is self-giving love, pursues and redeems a humanity that is fundamentally 'off the rails' and incapable of self-rescue.

subject.identificatie: The Triune God (Father, Son, Holy Spirit)
tekstueel_bewijs: God pursues us even beyond the grave
The love that persists in breaking through our resistance
He shall redeem Israel from all his iniquities

object.identificatie: Redemption/Deliverance from the 'vast primordial catastrophe' of sin.
tekstueel_bewijs: to redeem his entire creation from its impulse toward self-destruction

zender.identificatie: The Triune Nature of God (The 'Someone' who is eternal love)
tekstueel_bewijs: The inmost being of God is a dynamic interrelatedness that pours itself out

ontvanger.identificatie: The 'Miserable Offenders' (The Corinthian Church, the Psalmist, the Hearer)
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is explicitly positioned as the Receiver/Beneficiary of an action they cannot perform.

helper.identificatie: The Incarnation (Jesus Christ) and the Holy Spirit; secondary helpers are human 'hints' (parents, teachers).
tekstueel_bewijs: love that has become incarnate in history through Jesus Christ
helper.rol_van_god: God is both Subject and Helper (Mediator).

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin as a Cosmic Power, 'the depths', and human resistance/self-destruction.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is not described as a 'mistake' but as an ontological 'depth' and 'catastrophe' that makes human standing impossible.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of confession and 'fear of the Lord' as an entrance into the larger life of God.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer/Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (confession) is only possible because the primary program (God's mercy) is already active. 'Not the man who is lost, but the man who is about to be saved can understand that he is a sinner.'

voorbeelden_god_subject: God pursues us even beyond the grave
voorbeelden_mens_subject: the psalmist ceases to reflect upon himself

voorbeelden: things which we ought to have done
if you thought it might get your child’s attention
discovery that he is a God of infinite mercy
understand what is meant here by the fear of the Lord
total inability to present ourselves righteous

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes the 'Pouvoir-faire' (Power) of God in the face of the 'Non-pouvoir-faire' (Inability) of man. It is a classic Grace-oriented modal distribution.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from S2 (The Depths) to ~S1 (Rejecting the idea of merits) to S1 (Forgiveness/Fear of the Lord).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is found in the 'startling shift' where S2 is not ignored but becomes the site where S1 is manifest.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; the 'miserable offender' status is defended against modern deletions.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon consistently places God as the active Subject of salvation and defines the human condition as one of total inability, making grace a necessity rather than an accessory.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Imagine for a moment that you are the parent...

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as the Subject of active verbs
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: The God who pursues us even beyond the grave

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Human love (parents, aunts) is used as an example, but explicitly qualified as a 'hint' or 'glimmer' of the primary actor (God).
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already treats Paul not as a hero to imitate, but as a 'desperate' man pointing to God's Trinitarian grace.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and 'renewed confidence' through external rescue.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic undertones; salvation is entirely God's work.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the Trinitarian love (2 Cor) to the depths of sin (Ps 130) is logically and narratively tight.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'fear' and 'forgiveness' is the central semiotic pivot.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: The inmost being of God is a dynamic interrelatedness that pours itself out

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit is the 'fellowship' that brings the Subject's power to the Receiver.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a robustly theocentric narrative where God is the Subject of the primary program and humans are the receivers of a grace they cannot merit.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is the hallmark of a grace sermon.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Continue to contrast human 'non-pouvoir' with Divine 'pouvoir'.

tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: The 'miserable offender' language already provides maximum narrative tension.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in maintaining God as the Subject of the narrative engine while dealing honestly with the human condition.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'parent' metaphor's pathos, Greimas shows that the metaphor functions to establish the Sender's (God's) values of 'uncalculating love'.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the 'fear of the Lord'; semiotics shows how 'fear' functions as a modal competence (Savoir) resulting from the Object (Forgiveness).
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'miserable offender' language is not just 'old-fashioned' but a necessary narrative 'Opponent' to make the 'Subject' (God) truly heroic.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses Rutledge's grammar of grace effectively by making God the subject of the most critical verbs (save, redeem, pursue).
